title: How does writing shape our thinking? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t really have an opinion because I have read too much about it for too many years, and not properly digested what I read. (Or rather I have an excess of opinions and they all contradict each other). But if you forced me to throw together a graduate seminar to discuss the subject, and I had to write the syllabus this afternoon, I would assign the following books in a 15–week seminar (with the McLuhan, Eisenstein, and Pfitzer getting two weeks each and all the others getting one). Probably reaction paper and discussion once a week with students always urged to link that week’s work to a prior week’s work of their choice. Final assignment would be “Explain why this question is so hard to answer now that you’ve really thought about it.” The Gutenberg Galaxy, Marshall McLuhan Proust and the Squid: The Story and Science of the Reading Brain, Maryanne Wolf Propaganda: The Formation of Men's Attitudes, Jacques Ellul Popular History and the Literary Marketplace, 1840-1920 (Studies in Print Culture and the History of the Book), Gregory M. Pfitzer If You Want to Write: A Book about Art, Independence and Spirit, Brenda Ueland The Practice of Writing, David Lodge Dionysus Writes: The Invention of Theatre in Ancient Greece, Jennifer Wise The Pleasure of the Text, Roland Barthes, trans. Richard Miller The Printing Press as an Agent of Change, Elizabeth L. Eisenstein The Shallows: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains , Nicholas Carr Why Literature Is Bad for You, Peter Thorpe Writing To Learn, William Zinsser

Unlike any impetuous activity, writing is an act of unearthing the fragments of teeming reminiscence, flaming existence, and upcoming dreams. These fragments of thoughts are disoriented under the piling speculations, aspirations, conceptions, and condemnations. While settling somewhere down to jot down anything, our cognition streamlines the links that connect the near and distant relations of the mother thought. Moreover, it inspires to wander far and delve deep to find the withered roots once strived to fetch fresh water to our soul. Thereby, bringing the dispersed factions of the idea, writing helps to mold and beeline our thinking capacity.
